## {{< fa chart-simple >}} Distributions
### What Makes Them Unique?

::: {.callout-tip}
## **Question**

What uniquely determines a distribution?
:::

::: {.fragment}
One of three things:
:::

-   An [**MGF**]{.alert} (Moment-Generating Function)
-   A [**CDF/CMF**]{.alert} (Cumulative Distribution/Mass Function)
-   A [**PDF/PMF**]{.alert} (Probability Density/Mass Function)


## {{< fa chart-simple >}} Distributions
### What Makes Them Unique?

For Example:

-   If I tell you _X_ is a random variable with MGF _M_~_X_~(_t_) = e^_t_<sup>2</sup>^, you can immediately tell me that _X_ follows a Normal Distribution with mean 0 and variance 2.

-   If I tell you _Y_ is a random variable with density given by _f_~_Y_~(_y_) = 2<i>e</i><sup>-2<i>y</i></sup> for  _y_ > 0 and 0 otherwise, you can immediately tell me that _Y_ follows an Exponential Distribution with scale parameter 1/2.

::: {.fragment}
Not all distributions have names, but they can still be uniquely defined; e.g. a random variable _Z_ with density _f_~_Z_~(_z_) = π cos(π _z_) for 0 ≤ _z_ ≤ 1 and 0 otherwise
:::


## {{< fa bezier-curve >}} Transformations


::: {.callout-tip}
## **Goal**

Given a random variable _Y_ and a function _h_, we wish to identify the distribution of _U_ := _h_(_Y_).
:::

::: {.fragment}
Can be accomplished by finding:

-   The MGF of _U_ ([**MGF Method**]{.alert})
-   The CDF/CMF of _U_ ([**CDF Method**]{.alert})
-   The PDF/PMF of _U_ ([**Inverse Transformation Method**]{.alert}, or [**Change of Variable**]{.alert})

:::

::: {.fragment}
This is essentially the roadmap for the next few lectures/weeks in this course!
:::

## {{< fa bezier-curve >}} Transformations

Might seem abstract... but quite applicable!

-   [**Unit Conversion:**]{.alert} the temperature _C_ in Centigrade at a randomly-selected location in a city follows some distribution; what is the distribution of temperatures _F_ as measured in Fahrenheit?
    -   Example of a [**univariate**]{.alert} transformation; i.e. a transformation of only _one_ random variable

-   [**Data Summary:**]{.alert} given an i.i.d. collection of random variables, what is the distribution of the sample mean? Or, the sample variance? Or, the sample maximum?
    -   Examples of [**multivariate**]{.alert} transformations; i.e. transformations involving _multiple_ random variables

## {{< fa battery-three-quarters >}} Moment Generating Functions

::: {.callout-note}
## **Definition**

The [**Moment Generating Function**]{.alert} (MGF) for a random variable _Y_ is defined as $$ M_Y(t) := \mathbb{E}[e^{tY}] $$
:::

-   **Question for you:** When do we compute an MGF as a sum, and when do we compute it as an integral?

::: {.fragment}
::: {.callout-important}
## **Properties of MGFs**

1)    $M_{aY + b}(t) = e^{bt} M_Y(at)$
2)    For independent $X$ and $Y$, $M_{X + Y}(t) = M_X(t) \cdot M_Y(t)$
3)    [**Moment-Generating Property**]{.alert}: $M_Y^{(n)}(0) = \E[Y^n]$
:::
:::

## {{< fa battery-three-quarters >}} Moment Generating Functions {style="font-size:30px"}
### Example

::: {.fragment}
**Partially Worked-Out Example:** _Y_ ~ Exp(_β_) (note the parametrization being used in 120B is different from that in 120A!)
:::

::: {.fragment}
$$ M_Y(t) = \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{ty} \cdot \frac{1}{\beta} e^{-y/\beta} \ \mathrm{d}y = \frac{1}{\beta} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\left(\frac{1}{\beta} - t \right)y}  \ \mathrm{d}y $$
:::


-   This integral is finite only when $(\frac{1}{\beta} - t) > 0$; i.e. when $t < 1/\beta$. When it is finite:
\begin{align}
  \class{fragment}{{} M_Y(t)}
    &\class{fragment}{{} = \frac{1}{\beta} \cdot {\color{blue} \frac{1}{\left( \frac{1}{\beta} - t \right)} } \cdot  \int_{0}^{\infty} {\color{blue} \left( \frac{1}{\beta} - t \right) }  e^{-\left(\frac{1}{\beta} - t \right)y}  \ \mathrm{d}y}  \\[1mm]
    &\class{fragment}{{} = \frac{1}{\beta} \cdot  \frac{1}{\left( \frac{1}{\beta} - t \right)} = \frac{1}{1 - \beta t}}   \\[3mm]
\end{align}
